He didn’t get the question at first. 

“No, of course not. Here, take this one made of cypress wood. I have another, a copper one that belonged to Lizaveta. I swapped with her: she gave me her cross, and I gave her my little ikon. I’ll wear Lizaveta’s now and give you this one. Take it… it’s mine! It’s mine, you know,” she pleaded. “We will suffer together, and we’ll bear our cross together!” 

“Give it to me,” Raskolnikov said. He didn’t want to hurt her feelings. But he quickly pulled back his hand that was reaching for the cross. 

“Not now, Sonia. Better later,” he added to make her feel better. 

“Yes, yes, better,” she agreed firmly. “When you go to meet your suffering, then put it on. You’ll come to me, I’ll put it on you, we’ll pray and go together.” 

Just then, someone knocked three times on the door. 

“Sofya Semyonovna, may I come in?” they heard a familiar and polite voice say. 

Sonia rushed to the door, startled. The flaxen head of Mr. Lebeziatnikov peeked in.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Sonia offers Raskolnikov a cross to symbolize their shared suffering, but he hesitates to accept it immediately.
